subject: Public Speaking
title: Working Memory Under Pressure
description: A micro-lesson that makes Working Memory Under Pressure usable.

hook.text: Your working memory can hold about four chunks of information at once. Anxiety steals at least one of those slots.

buildup.text: When anxious, part of your working memory gets occupied by worry, self-monitoring, and threat scanning.

discovery.text: This is why nervous speakers lose their place, repeat themselves, or suddenly can't find simple words.

twist.text: Expert speakers don't have more working memory. They've automated so much that anxiety can't steal enough to matter.

climax.text: The solution isn't calming down. It's practicing until your speech runs on autopilot, freeing memory for adaptation.

punchline.text: Practice doesn't kill fear. It makes fear irrelevant.

quiz.question: Why do anxious speakers lose their place?
options: Anxiety occupies working memory slots needed for the speech
